member.name: T:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager
member.summary: Defines the console manager.

member.name: P:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager.HasConsole
member.summary: Indicates whether the current program has a console.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager.Show
member.summary: Creates a new console instance if the process is not attached to a console already.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager.Hide
member.summary: If the process has a console attached to it, it will be detached and no longer visible. Writing to the System.Console is still possible, but no output will be shown.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager.Toggle
member.summary: Toggles the console.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager.AllocConsole
member.summary: Allocates a new console for the calling process.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: A process can be associated with only one console, so the AllocConsole function fails if the calling process already has a console. A process can use the function to detach itself from its current console, then it can call to create a new console or AttachConsole to attach to another console.
If the calling process creates a child process, the child inherits the new console.

initializes standard input, standard output, and standard error handles for the new console. The standard input handle is a handle to the console's input buffer, and the standard output and standard error handles are handles to the console's screen buffer. To retrieve these handles, use the GetStdHandle function.

This function is primarily used by a graphical user interface (GUI) application to create a console window. GUI applications are initialized without a console. Console applications are initialized with a console, unless they are created as detached processes (by calling the CreateProcess function with the DETACHED_PROCESS flag).

member.name: M:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager.FreeConsole
member.summary: Detaches the calling process from its console.

returns.para: If the function succeeds, the return value is nonzero.
If the function fails, the return value is zero. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: A process can be attached to at most one console. If the calling process is not already attached to a console, the error code returned is ERROR_INVALID_PARAMETER (87).

A process can use the function to detach itself from its console. If other processes share the console, the console is not destroyed, but the process that called cannot refer to it. A console is closed when the last process attached to it terminates or calls . After a process calls FreeConsole, it can call the function to create a new console or AttachConsole to attach to another console.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager.GetConsoleOutputCP
member.summary: Retrieves the output code page used by the console associated with the calling process. A console uses its output code page to translate the character values written by the various output functions into the images displayed in the console window.

returns.para: The return value is a code that identifies the code page. For a list of identifiers, see Code Page Identifiers.
If the return value is zero, the function has failed. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

remarks.para: A code page maps 256 character codes to individual characters. Different code pages include different special characters, typically customized for a language or a group of languages. To retrieve more information about a code page, including it's name, see the GetCPInfoEx function.
To set a console's output code page, use the SetConsoleOutputCP function. To set and query a console's input code page, use the SetConsoleCP and GetConsoleCP functions.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.ConsoleManager.GetConsoleWindow
member.summary: Retrieves the window handle used by the console associated with the calling process.
member.returns: The return value is a handle to the window used by the console associated with the calling process or (or in C#) if there is no such associated console.

i.b: This document describes console platform functionality that is no longer a part of our ecosystem roadmap. We do not recommend using this content in new products, but we will continue to support existing usages for the indefinite future. Our preferred modern solution focuses on virtual terminal sequences for maximum compatibility in cross-platform scenarios. You can find more information about this design decision in our classic console vs. virtual terminal document.

remarks.para: To compile an application that uses this function, define _WIN32_WINNT as 0x0500 or later. For more information, see Using the Windows Headers.

para.b: This API is not recommended and does not have a virtual terminal equivalent. This decision intentionally aligns the Windows platform with other operating systems. This state is only relevant to the local user, session, and privilege context. Applications remoting via cross-platform utilities and transports like SSH may not work as expected if using this API.

remarks.para: For an application that is hosted inside a pseudoconsoles session, this function returns a window handle for message queue purposes only. The associated window is not displayed locally as the pseudoconsole is serializing all actions to a stream for presentation on another terminal window elsewhere.

member.summary: Indicates the event type that the Amiable is able to trigger.

member.name: M:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.IPluginEventHandler.Process(Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.AmiableEventArgs)
member.summary: To process the operation via the event arguments.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventSubType
member.summary: Indicates the subtype of the event that is not defined by Onebot protocol.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventSubType.FRIEND
member.summary: Indicates the subtype is from a friend. The subtype is used for a C2C window.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventSubType.GROUP
member.summary: Indicates the subtype is from a group (temporary message). The subtype is used for a C2C window.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventSubType.OTHER
member.summary: Indicates the subtype is from other people. The subtype is used for a C2C window.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventSubType.NORMAL
member.summary: Indicates the subtype is a normal message. The subtype is used for a QQ group window.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventSubType.ANONYMOUS
member.summary: Indicates the subtype is an anonymous message. The subtype is used for a QQ group window.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventSubType.NOTICE
member.summary: Indicates the subtype is a noticce message. The subtype is used for a QQ group window.

member.name: T:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventType
member.summary: Indicates the event type that is defined by Onebot protocol.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventType.C2C
member.summary: Indicates the message type is from C2C.

member.name: F:Sudoku.Bot.Oicq.Concepts.MessageEventType.Group
member.summary: Indicates the message type is from group.
